channel.title: [TUT] Guide to SCAR
channel.description:
[center][img]http://img186.imageshack.us/img186/411/tutltm2nt7.jpg[/img][/center]
[center] [u][b]Guide to SCAR by Bebemycat2[/b][/u][/center]
In this Tutorial I will show you where things are located in SCAR CDE 2.03. Inspired by Khain (Most people wont know who he is, but some of the older member might).
Tutorial:
This is the Main Window of SCAR:
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/9987/scarmwsl4.jpg[/img]
Top Section: Here are the most used icons and their explanation:
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/520/newscriptsif0.jpg[/img] This will clear all the current data in SCAR (prompting you if you want to save) and creates a fresh script outline.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/992/openscriptqq6.jpg[/img] This will give you the option of opening a script located anywhere on your computer. By default it opens in the SCAR scripts folder located in the SCAR directory.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/7937/savescriptxw0.jpg[/img] This will give you the option to save the current script loaded by SCAR.
[img]http://img186.imageshack.us/img186/8020/cuttx1.jpg[/img] Your standard cut option, available in almost every program. Will cut certain code and save it to the "clipboard" for later use.
[img]http://img186.imageshack.us/img186/7111/copyyx1.jpg[/img] Same as the "Cut" option but insteed of erasing the set of code, it will keep it visible.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/765/pastegm9.jpg[/img] This is what you can use to "paste" the code selected with the "Cut" and "Copy" options.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/9058/searchkd4.jpg[/img] Here you can search for certain key works in the SCAR script.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/4910/runscriptzy2.jpg[/img] This will run the script loaded by SCAR.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/1958/pausescriptpb5.jpg[/img] This will pause the currently running script.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/3001/stopscriptfp1.jpg[/img] This will stop the currently running script.
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/2047/colorpickercb5.jpg[/img] This is perhaps the most useful tool in SCAR, it is a color picker. Click it and your screen will freeze allowing you to pick a color out. The color will be printed into the Debug box in scar, along with the coordinates of the color within th selected client.
[img]http://img186.imageshack.us/img186/2933/cleardebuglogdd8.jpg[/img] This will clear the Debug box
[img]http://img218.imageshack.us/img218/6741/crosshairjb0.jpg[/img] This is what you use to select the client window.
After reading the above you may be asking yourself "Where/what is the Debug window/box?" Well not to worry, that would be this: [IMG]http://img213.imageshack.us/img213/2176/debugbox3tk.jpg[/img]
[center][b]This concludes this Tutorial.... for now....[/b][/center]
[center][img]http://img186.imageshack.us/img186/4790/tutltm3pe7.jpg[/img][/center]
*Note, so people know, this isn't done yet, so don't criticize it too hard :P

item.title: [TUT] Guide to SCAR
item.dc:creator: @Bebemycat2 Bebe
item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

Oh, about API calls

“They aren’t SCAR’s really…
Api calls are calls to functions precoded into the os, the win32 api is what SCAR uses to work, all programs do…
The problem with the api is that the functions are very specific, they each have their own special function and to create for example a simple macro with a findcolor functions you will need several api calls…
These are pretty useless in SCAR though, for the reason that 1 they aren’t standardly enabled (which is good)…
2 They’re alot slower when called from SCAR
And finally, SCAR’s precoded functions are alot more useful to use…
However, you can use api calls in plugins…
Well, you usually don’t even have a choice”

Thank you Freddy for clearing that up for me

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT] Guide to SCAR
item.dc:creator: @Bebemycat2 Bebe
item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

Don’t hold me to this, but I believe it would be:

When you are making a program, say a macro for RS, and you want to use a SCAR function, you can allow API calls, and code your programs to use certain functions from SCAR.

Edit:

I just found out that they are probably for controlling Windows API.

Hell I don’t know, you got me…

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT] Guide to SCAR
item.dc:creator: @bullzeye95 bullzeye
item.description:
@bullzeye95 wrote:

When you say ““Remote””… huh?

Do you mean it can tell SCAR to do, or what?

Read full topic

item.title: [TUT] Guide to SCAR
item.dc:creator: @Bebemycat2 Bebe
item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

[quote=“bullzeye, post:2, topic:34263”]I have a question. What does “Allow API Calls” do?

Oh, and you spelled listen wrong :P[/quote]
Just assume that is a “n” I’ll fix it later.

Api stands for: application programming interface

And from what I understand it allows another program to use SCAR as a “Remote”.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Bebemycat2 wrote:

[center][/center]

[center]
Guide to SCAR by Bebemycat2[/center]

In this Tutorial I will show you where things are located in SCAR CDE 2.03. Inspired by Khain (Most people wont know who he is, but some of the older member might).

Tutorial:

This is the Main Window of SCAR:

Top Section:
Here are the most used icons and their explanation:


This will clear all the current data in SCAR (prompting you if you want to save) and creates a fresh script outline.


This will give you the option of opening a script located anywhere on your computer. By default it opens in the SCAR scripts folder located in the SCAR directory.


This will give you the option to save the current script loaded by SCAR.


Your standard cut option, available in almost every program. Will cut certain code and save it to the “clipboard” for later use.


Same as the “Cut” option but insteed of erasing the set of code, it will keep it visible.


This is what you can use to “paste” the code selected with the “Cut” and “Copy” options.


Here you can search for certain key works in the SCAR script.


This will run the script loaded by SCAR.


This will pause the currently running script.


This will stop the currently running script.


This is perhaps the most useful tool in SCAR, it is a color picker. Click it and your screen will freeze allowing you to pick a color out. The color will be printed into the Debug box in scar, along with the coordinates of the color within th selected client.


This will clear the Debug box


This is what you use to select the client window.

After reading the above you may be asking yourself “Where/what is the Debug window/box?” Well not to worry, that would be this:

[center]This concludes this Tutorial… for now…[/center]

[center][/center]
